clinical_study.brief_title: BIA Guided-fluid Management in Open Abdomen
clinical_study.official_title: Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis Guided-Fluid Management Promotes Fascial Closure of Open Abdomen

brief_summary.textblock: High volume fluid therapy in open abdomen (OA) trauma patients contributes to excessive visceral edema, delayed fascial closure, and prolonged parenteral nutrition. Thus, we investigated whether bioelectrical impedance analysis-directed resuscitation reduced postoperative fluid overload, and improved outcomes in OA trauma patients.

primary_outcome.description: 100% direct approximation of abdominal fascial edges

secondary_outcome.description: Postoperative 7-day fluid balancepostoperative fluid use during ICU

arm_group.description: BIA-directed fluid resuscitation The protocol for patients assigned to BIA-directed resuscitation was as follows. A 500-ml bolus of crystalloid was applied every 30 min to maintain central venous pressure (CVP) of 8 to 10 mmHg. If mean arterial pressure (MAP) was below 65 mmHg, vasopressors were provided to maintain a mean arterial pressure of >65 mmHg. If HL > 73.3 %, fluid infusion was restricted, and a furosemide drip and CRRT were initiated with an ultrafiltration rate that gave a negative fluid balance to maintain the central venous pressure, mean arterial pressure, and HL. Patients were usually beside the bed or taken back to the operating room within 2 days for attempted primary closure. If the abdomen could not be closed after several attempts, then the abdomen was closed with biologics or skin grafting with a planned ventral hernia repair at a later date.

Traditional fluid resuscitation Briefly, a 500-ml bolus of crystalloid was given every 30 min to achieve a CVP of 8-12 mm Hg. Vasopressors, vasodilators, and dobutamine were given to maintain appropriate MAP with central venous oxygen saturation (ScvO2). Red cells were transfused to promote ScvO2 when <70%.

intervention.description: A multi-frequency BIA with eight tactile electrodes (Inbody S10 Biospace, Biospace Co. Ltd., Seoul, Korea) was used to assess body fluid status within the first 24 h after admission to the ICU and daily every 24 h.

study_pop.textblock: All trauma patients requiring damage control laparotomy with nonclosure of the abdominal fascia were admitted to the Surgical Intensive Care Unit (SICU), identified and prospectively followed during the study period.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- The inclusion criterion was fascial nonclosure after the initial trauma laparotomy.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Patients younger than 18 years-of-age and those who were pregnant were excluded.
